Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A scalable platform to produce nematode pheromones for crop protection
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to create a manufacturing method for a new class of environmentally friendly, sustainable biopesticides. Chemical pesticides pollute the environment and cause harm to humans and other nontarget organisms. In contrast, biopesticides are safe to humans and the environment. The proposed project is a platform to manufacture special chemicals to enhance food security and sustainable agricultural practices. <br/><br/>The proposed SBIR Phase I project addresses the feasibility of manufacturing nematode dispersal pheromones using in vitro fermentation to control agricultural pests. Entomopathogenic nematodes are natural bioinsecticides commercially produced using in vitro fermentation; they produce pheromones that can greatly enhance their efficacy as biocontrol agents. This project will demonstrate the feasibility of manufacturing nematode dispersal pheromones using in vitro fermentation methods with the following technical tasks: 1) An in vitro fermentation system will be established using Steinernema feltiae in shaker flasks; 2) Optimum harvesting time for dispersal pheromones will be determined using dispersal assays; 3) The effectiveness of the produced pheromones will be compared with that of in vivo counterparts for dispersal and infectivity; 4) Media will be supplemented to boost pheromone production and create a platform for specific pheromone mixtures.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During SBIR Phase I project, we created a scalable nematode pheromone manufacturing platform that will allow us to bring nematode pheromones to the market for eco-friendly, sustainable, pest control. While doing this, we established a routine fermentation process for nematode pheromones, tested the pheromones in field trials, and conducted market research. We conducted market research to establish a commercial need for our product and discovered broad support for using nematode pheromones for agricultural pest control among growers, pest control advisors, and ag-input companies. Even conventional growers are turning to biopesticides to bolster their integrated pest management programs.  We established a routine, small-scale pheromone fermentation in shaker flasks and tested the pheromones we produced to confirm that the beneficial nematode dispersal and infectivity activities were present. We also eliminated a toxic solvent from our extraction process, making the manufacturing process more environmentally friendly. Farmers and potential commercial partners we spoke to during our market research wanted to know about our products' field effectiveness and potential unintended consequences. We conducted field trials to test pheromone-treated beneficial nematodes' field effectiveness. We also tested the soil microbiome to see if putting nematode pheromones in the field had any unintended consequences. We found that beneficial nematodes treated with pheromones are more effective and that both beneficial nematodes and pheromone extracts improve soil health without any unintended consequences. We are ready to scale our nematode pheromone fermentation platform in bioreactors to bring this technology to the market. Phase I laid a solid foundation for Phase II scale-up and pilot production for manufacturing, testing, and commercialization.


Last Modified: 08/02/2022
Modified by: Fatma Kaplan
